coredata.dc:title: Metal cluster—rare gas van der Waals complexes: Nb n Ar m and Fe n Kr m
coredata.dc:creator: Knickelbein, Mark B.
Menezes, Warren J.C.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Van der Waals complexes of niobium clusters with argon atoms and iron clusters with krypton atoms have been produced in a supersonic expansion using a laser vaporization cluster source cooled to 77 K. Laser photoionization time-of-flight mass spectra reveal significant nonmonotonic cluster size dependence in the extent of formation for both Nb n Ar m and Fe n Kr species. Photoionization efficiency (PIE) spectra have been recorded for selected Nb n Ar m species for n⩽20. For a given n, ionization potentials (IPs) assigned from PIE threshold behavior decrease with increasing m, as predicted by a simple charge-induced dipole electrostatic model.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LE ITI ERS 4 October 1991 Metal cluster rare gas van der Waals complexes: NbnArm and FenKrm Mark B. Knickelbein and Warren J.C. Menezes Chemist ryDivision, Argonne National Laboratory. Argonne, IL 60439, USA Received 19April 1991; iii final form 15 July 1991 Van der Waals complexes of niobium clusters with argon atoms and iron clusters with krypton atoms lave been produced in a supersonic expansion using a laser vaporization cluster source cooled to 77 K. Laser photoionization time-of-flight mass spectra reveal significant nonmonotonic cluster size dependence in the extent of formation for both 1 4b~Ar,,, and Fe~Kr species. Photoion- ization efficiency (PIE) spectra have been recorded for selected Nb~Ar,,, species for n ~ 20. For a given n, ionization potentials (IPs) assigned from PIE threshold behavior decrease with increasing m, as predicted by a simple charge-induced dipole electro- static model. 1. Introduction The results of experimental studies of metal clus- ters are often interpreted by drawing on the close as- sociation with corresponding phenomena on bulk metal surfaces, A wealth of valuable information re- garding the nature of metal clusters has been ob- tained, for example, through their chemisorption behavior toward a variety of small molecular spe- cies, where dramatic variation with cluster size has been observed for the rate and extent of reaction [1]. In this Letter we extend this metal cluster surface analogy and report model systems of metal rare gas physisorption in the microscopic domain: van der Waals complexes of transition metal clusters with rare gas atoms, ~ Specifically, we have obtained laser photoionization time-of-flight mass spectra of NbnArm and Fe~Kr species produced using a cooled cluster source as well as photoionizalion efficiency spectra of selected NbnAr,,, species. There have been several recent spectroscopie stud- ies of rare gas van der Waals complexes containing one or two metal atoms. High-resolution laser-in- duced fluorescence spectra of neutral metal atom rare gas diatomic complexes, MR, have yielded in- formation on bond strengths and vibrational fre- quencies for ground and excited electronic states of lhese species [2 5], while similar information has been obtained for ionic complexes MR~ via their photofragmentat ion excitation spectra [6 8]. Stud- ies of neutral and ionic MRm complexes (m> 1) have provided information regarding the solvation of the central metal atom by the surrounding rare gas atoms [9,10]. Lessen and Brucat have reported a photodissociation study of the Ni2Ar~ complex whereby an estimate of the dissociation energy of Ni~ was obtained [111. Recently, Cheng et al. have obtained the vibrationally resolved electronic spec- trum of Ag2Ar, from which excited state vibrational frequencies and Ag2 Ar binding energies were ob- tained [12]. Here we present examples of rare gas van der Waals complexes of polyatomic metal clusters. For these species, a nonspherically symmetric metal rare gas potential is imposed by the metal clusters surface structure . The most obvious manifestation of metal cluster surface topology appears in the distribution of MnR,~, products where we observe that certain metal clusters form rare gas adducts easily while oth- ers appear to be relatively inert toward complex for- mation. This size specificity in complex formation contains important information regarding cluster ge- ometry complimentary to that obtained using chem- ical probe methods in which the uptake of small mol- ecules such as ammonia and water is exploited to 433 0009-2614/91/s 03.50 1991 Elsevier Science Publishers 8V. All rights reserved. CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 Volume 184, number 5,~ obium and iron clusters at n= 7 and 10, respectively. Generally, the rate of complex formation in the supersonic expansion will depend on the local gas temperature, the density of metal clusters and of rare gas atoms and the rate of stabilizing third body collisions, with formation favored at high gas den- sities (i.e. high collision rate) and low temperatures [14]. We expect a priori that under given expansion conditions and gas composition, the probability of formation of the van der Waals complex M~R will increase with metal cluster size, following the in- crease in geometric cross section for complex-form- ing collisions and for M~R He inelastic collisions. The latter are essential to stabilize the nascent, en- ergy-rich complexes MARt toward dissociation back to reactants, M~+R. The unimolecular lifetimes of nascent M~R~ complexes should likewise increase with cluster size, due to the concomitant increase in the number of internal degrees of freedom. An ex- amination of the TOF spectra, however, reveals a significant, nonmonotonic variation in the apparent efficiency of complex formation with increasing cluster size, indicating a somewhat more compli- cated process than that predicted by simple kinettc arguments. As shown in fig. 1, Nb5 and Nb5 appear to be relatively inert toward complex formation, whereas for Nb7 Nb11, complexes form readily, with Nb~Ar signal intensities of a similar magnitude to those of the bare clusters. However, Nb12Ar com- plexes are formed with significantly less relative in- tensity than those for n = 7 11. Similarly, as shown in fig. 2, Fe~Kr formation commences abruptly at n= 10, with essentially no complexes forming with smaller iron clusters under these experimental con- ditions. We observe that Fe10Kr Fe12Kr intensities are approximately equal in magnitude, while Fe13Kr is absent. Formation of Fe~Kr is again observed for n = 14 and 15 but not for n = 16 etc. Ionization of M~R,,, species at photon energies greater than 0.1 eV above their IPs (as in figs. 1 and 2) may be accompanied by loss of one or more rare gas atoms. If such dissociative ionization pro- cesses occur on a time scale faster than ion extrac- tion (~ 1 is), the relative peak intensities in the mass spectra will not reflect the abundance of neutral spe- cies in the molecular beam. 1f these time scales are similar, asymmetric TOF peak broadening will be infer the number and nature metal cluster surface binding sites [1]. 2. Experimental methods The experimental apparatus and general methods for cluster production and photoionization spectros- copy have been described in detail elsewhere [13]. Briefly, metal atoms are generated using a laser va- porization source employing continuous helium flows (600 700 seem). Metal clusters grow and cool via collisions with helium (~ 15 20 Torr) within a 7.6 cm X 0.32 cm (length X inner diameter) flow tube maintained at 77 K. The metal clusters reside 1 ms in the flow tube before expanding into vacuum through a 0.13 cm diameter orifice opening into a 15 (half angle) conical nozzle 1.2cm in length. To generate the van der Waals complexes, a small frac- tion of rare gas (0.3 5% Kr, 3 10% Ar) is added to the helium carrier gas. The expanding free jet is skimmed to form a mo- lecular beam, which passes through a second differ- entially pumped vacuum stage and finally into a de- tection chamber. The molecular beam is intersected at 90 by a pulsed LV dye laser within the ion ex- traction region of a time-of-flight (TOF) mass spec- trometer. The mass separated cluster photoions are detected by a microchannel plate, the output of which is amplified, digitized and stored in a minicomputer as TOF spectra. Photoionization efficiency (PIE) spectra are generated by recording mass peak areas as a function of laser wavelength at 0.25 nm wave- length intervals and normalizing peak areas for ion- ization laser fluence. Laser fluence is kept below 400 ~tJ cm2 to minimize multiphoton effects. Multiple wavelength scans are added to improve signal-to- noise ratios in the PIE spectra. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Time-of-flight spectra The time-of-flight mass spectra for Nb~Arm (n = 5 12) and Fe~Kr (n= 10 23) are shown in figs. 1 and 2, respectively. A relatively sharp size onset for (sig- nificant) complex formation is observed for both ni- 434 n m Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 Nb~Ar 12 m n ~ m ~ Fig. 1. Time-of-flight spectrum Nb, and Nb,Ar,,, recorded at 209.75 nm (5.91 eV). P~ 20 Torr, He:Ar= 15: Fe ~ Krm 10 o 12 13 0 0 ~ 14 15 1 0 0 C I 2 22 23 I O Q 15 Fig. 2. Time-of-flight spectrum of Fe, and Fe,K.r recorded at 211.6 nm (5.86 eV). P,,~ 20 Tore, He:Kr= 30: 1. The peaks of Fe8.-Fe2, have been truncated. observed if a significant fraction of the M,,R,. com- plexes undergoes dissociation. Mass spectra of Nb,, and Fe,, clusters recorded using pure helium carrier gas show that the shapes and widths of the M, and M,,R,, mass peaks are due solely to instrumental broadening and to the overlap of minor impurity peaks. Furthermore, it is expected from both ener- getics and kinetics considerations that the extent of fragmentation should scale with increasing photon energy above ionization threshold (i.e. with increas- ing internal energy available) whereas we do not ob- serve any correlation of the product distributions with the ionization potentials of either Nb, [151 or Fe, [16]. While we cannot rule out dissociative ioni- zation on a fast ( < I ps) time scale, it is unlikely that this phenomenon is responsible for the large varia- tions in relative M,,Rm intensity observed in the mass spectra. Proceeding under the assumption that the ob- served relative mass peak intensities are reasonable approximations to the true distribution of neutral M, and M,,R,,, species, we propose that the variations in the efficiency of van der Waals complex formation can be traced to size-dependent metal cluster sur- face structure . Because the probability of complex formation is determined in large part by the M, R attractive potential, metal clusters which possess sites supporting a strong M, R van der Waals bond are expected to form complexes with greater prob- ability than those with shallower M,, R potentials. The observed variations in complex formation effi- ciency with cluster size thus contain information bearing on cluster surface topology. The systematic investigation of these variations may be a potentially valuable tool in the difficult task of metal cluster structure determination. 435 6 9 0 9 10 ~1 12 O s 7~ 11 ji 1 2 II i~JifliIL 1 18 19 20 O~ ii i1~ 21 14 15 Volume 184, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October l9~l 3.2. PIE spectra and ionization potentials We have recorded the PIE spectra of Nb5Ar,,, Nb12Ar,,, and NbisArm Nb2oAr,,, for mzs3. The ob- served ionization thresholds of the argon complexes are shifted to slightly lower energies with respect to the bare niobium cluster, approximately linearly with increasing m, as shown in figs. 3 and 4 for NbsArm and Nb20Ar,, species. Using the vertical IPs, as- signed by extrapolation of the near threshold portion of the PIE spectra to baseline [13], we obtain the average IP shifts per bound argon atom. These IF shifts, hereafter denoted i.MP/~m, are plotted in fig. 5 as a function of cluster size (n). In cases where bare niobium clusters or cluster argon complexes may be present as multiple isomers (as found for Nb9 Nb12 115]), the ionization potential assignments neces- sarily correspond to the isomer possessing the lowest IP. In most cases, the shapes of the PIE spectra for Nb,,Ar,,, complexes are not significantly different than those displayed by the corresponding bare niobium clusters Nb,,: the spectra are simply shifted to lower energies with increasing m as shown for Nb20Ar,,, in fig. 4. Such behavior is expected under the assump- tion that weakly bound argon atoms represent a neg- ligible perturbation to the electronic and geometric structures of the underlying metal clusters and hence do not appreciably change their photoionization characteristics. The spectra for some complexes, including NbsArm (fig. 3) and Nb11Ar,,, are somewhat different in overall shape than those of the corresponding bare metal clusters. Furthermore, as shown in fig. 3, the PIE spectrum for bare Nb9 recorded simultaneously with Nb9Ar,, complexes (i.e. with argon present in the expansion) displays a different threshold shape than that recorded using pure helium carrier gas, al- though the observed ionization threshold energies are the same. Similar behavior is observed for Nb1~ Be- cause Nb9 Nb12 are produced as (at least) two iso- mers under the source conditions employed here [15], the PIE spectra for these clusters (and prob- ably those of the corresponding van der Waals spe- cies) are composites with contributions from differ- ent isomers. In general, it is expected that each cluster isomer will form complexes with different efficiency, such that the more reactive isomer is selectively photon energy (ev) Fig. 3. Photoionizatiors efficiency spectra of Nb,, and Nb,,Ar,, species. Arrows denote vertical IP assignments. depleted via complex formation, hence changing the ratio of the remaining bare cluster isomers. Photoionization efficiency spectra of Nb2,, and Nb20Ar,,, species with vertical IFs denoted. clusters and their van der Waals complexes can be reasonably interpreted as arising from the presence of multiple isomers, other processes such as disso- ciative ionization or intrinsic differences in the pho- toionization band shapes may give rise to this be- havior as well. These issues will be discussed in more detail in a future publication [171. 3.3. IP shifts: an electrostatic model For the following discussion, we will assume that the ions of the metal clusters and their van der Waals complexes have approximately the same geometric structure as the corresponding neutral species, so that we may take the measured vertical IPs to be reason- 7- E o CO > a) E o. Fig. 5. Average ionization potential shifts per bound Ar atom for niobium clusters as a function of cluster size n. Solid curve: eq. (2) witha= 1.64 A3,R= l.20n ~ Aand o= I.OA. ably good approximations to the corresponding adi- abaticlPs [13]. A simple Born cycle energetics analysis predicts that an adsorbed rare gas atom will shift the adi- abatic IP of a metal cluster by an amount deter- mined by the difference in cluster atom binding en- ergy D0 between the neutral complex and the ion: AlP/Am = IP ( M,,R) IP (M,,) (1) The difference in binding energy AD~ is given to first order by the additional charge-induced dipole po- tential present in the ionic complex. Classical elec- trostatic theory predicts that for a conducting sphere (cluster) or radius R and charge e in the presence of a polarizable body (argon atom), the induced dipole potential is given by ae2/21 4 where tz is the polar- izability of the external body (1.64 A3 for Ar [18]) and lis the distance of the body from the center of the sphere. Applying this prediction for AD0 to the M,, R system and using eq. (1), we obtain iMP/Li,n=cxe2/2(R+~5)4, (2) where o is the effective distance of the rare gas atom from the cluster surface such that R + 0=!. Without prior knowledge of the Nb,, Ar bond lengths it is im- possible to uniquely specify R and 0, however, by setting o= 1.0 A (a lower bound estimate), a rea- sonable fit of eq. (2) to the experimental AlP/Am values is obtained with the cluster radii calculated as R=yn~ 3, with 3=1.20 A as shown in fig. 5. This 10 20 cluster size (atoms) 437 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 October 1991 Volume 184, number 5,6 value of y is 26% smaller than that describing the packing of bulk (bcc) niobium. If a larger value of o is assumed (internuclear distances of >3 A have been observed for same diatomic MAr complexes [4,5] L the value of y required to fit the data set is smaller still. Because this model assumes a smooth cluster surface, it is unable to account for variations in M,, R distances due to changing binding configurations with increasing cluster size. In principle, these vari- ations would be observed as fine structure super- imposed on the overall (R+o)~4 dependence of the IP shifts. However, because the uncertainty in the measured IF shifts are nearly as large as the shifts themselves, we do not expect such measurements to be capable of resolving changes in cluster surface topology. While these results suggest that the atomic packing density in niobium clusters is higher than that of the bulk metal, it is possible that some of the assump- tions invoked in this simple electrostatic model, such as charge delocalization and spherical cluster sym- metry, may not be valid for these microscopic sys- tems and hence may lead to erroneous conclusions. We note that EXAFS studies, capable of providing a direct measure of nearest neighbor interatomic spacings, have indicated size contractions for iron [19], copper [201 and nickel [20] clusters, as com- pared to those expected from bulk atomic packing densities. 4. Conclusions Van der Waals complexes of metal clusters with rare gas atoms have been efficiently produced by cooling a laser vaporization cluster source to 77 K. Variations in complex formation efficiency with in- creasing cluster size appear to reflect the evolution of metal cluster surface topology as reflected in changes in M,, R potential minima; such variations may provide important clues bearing on cluster geo- metric structure. Additional experiments exploiting van der Waals complex formation as a surface-sen- sitive probe of metal cluster structure will be de- scribed in a future paper [17]. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Van der Waals complexes of niobium clusters with argon atoms and iron clusters with krypton atoms have been produced in a supersonic expansion using a laser vaporization cluster source cooled to 77 K. Laser photoionization time-of-flight mass spectra reveal significant nonmonotonic cluster size dependence in the extent of formation for both Nb n Ar m and Fe n Kr species. Photoionization efficiency (PIE) spectra have been recorded for selected Nb n Ar m species for n⩽20. For a given n, ionization potentials (IPs) assigned from PIE threshold behavior decrease with increasing m, as predicted by a simple charge-induced dipole electrostatic model.
